framework.name: QIF — Quantum Indeterministic Framework for Neural Security

ai_transparency.statement: This framework was developed collaboratively between Kevin Qi (human researcher) and AI assistants. All AI involvement is assistive — Kevin retains authorship and all decision-making authority.
ai_transparency.audit_trail_description: Complete chronological record of every derivation, decision, AI contribution, and validation result — with timestamps, reasoning chains, and source attribution.

neural.name: Neural Domain
neural.description: Biological processing from spinal cord to neocortex — 7 bands, severity-stratified

silicon.name: Silicon Domain
silicon.description: Classical: analog front-end through digital processing to application/wireless

bands.name: Neocortex
bands.description: PFC, M1, S1, V1, A1, Broca, Wernicke, association cortex — executive function, language, movement, perception
bands.severity_description: Cognitive impairment, motor paralysis, sensory loss, language disruption

bands.name: Limbic System
bands.description: Hippocampus, amygdala, insula, ACC, cingulate — emotion, memory, interoception
bands.severity_description: Memory erasure, emotional dysregulation, PTSD trigger, addiction manipulation

bands.name: Basal Ganglia
bands.description: Striatum, GPi/GPe, STN, substantia nigra — motor selection, reward, habit
bands.severity_description: Movement disorders (Parkinson's, dystonia), reward hijacking, compulsive behavior

bands.name: Diencephalon
bands.description: Thalamus, hypothalamus — sensory gating, consciousness relay, autonomic regulation
bands.severity_description: Consciousness disruption, sensory blackout, sleep-wake cycle attack, thermal regulation failure

bands.name: Cerebellum
bands.description: Cerebellar cortex, deep nuclei, vermis — motor coordination, timing, learning
bands.severity_description: Ataxia, coordination loss, speech disruption (dysarthria), motor learning impairment

bands.name: Brainstem
bands.description: Medulla, pons, midbrain, cranial nerve nuclei — vital functions, arousal, reflexes
bands.severity_description: Respiratory arrest, cardiac failure, loss of consciousness, cranial nerve paralysis

bands.name: Spinal Cord
bands.description: Cervical, thoracic, lumbar, sacral, cauda equina — reflexes, peripheral motor/sensory relay
bands.severity_description: Paralysis (quadri/para), bladder/bowel dysfunction, chronic pain, autonomic dysreflexia

bands.name: Neural Interface
bands.severity_description: Interface degradation, impedance failure, tissue damage, signal corruption

bands.name: Analog / Near-Field
bands.description: Amplification, filtering, ADC/DAC, near-field EM (0 Hz – 10 kHz)
bands.severity_description: Signal corruption, ADC saturation, impedance artifact

bands.name: Digital / Telemetry
bands.description: Decoding, classification, telemetry, MICS (10 kHz – 1 GHz)
bands.severity_description: Data corruption, BLE exploit, MICS intermodulation, firmware compromise

bands.name: Radio / Wireless / DE
bands.description: RF, wireless links, directed energy, application layer (1 GHz+)
bands.severity_description: RF hijack, directed energy, cloud compromise, supply chain attack
bci_devices: BLE/WiFi consumer, satellite links, DE weapons

S1_cortex.note: Primary somatosensory cortex (renamed to avoid collision with S1 band)

CeA.note: Central amygdala — autonomic output, but limbic origin

GPi.note: Globus pallidus interna — primary output nucleus

STN.note: Subthalamic nucleus — #1 DBS target for Parkinson's

hypothalamus.note: Autonomic master regulator — temperature, hunger, circadian

VIM.note: Ventral intermediate nucleus — DBS target for essential tremor

ANT.note: Anterior nucleus of thalamus — DBS target for epilepsy

medulla.note: Contains respiratory and cardiovascular centers — compromise is LETHAL

reticular_formation.note: Ascending arousal system — attack = loss of consciousness

sacral_cord.note: S1-S5 — bladder, bowel, sexual function. InterStim target.

determinacy_spectrum.name: Stochastic → Chaotic
determinacy_spectrum.description: Thalamic gating transitions between stochastic relay and chaotic oscillation

determinacy_spectrum.name: Chaotic
determinacy_spectrum.description: Deterministic but sensitive to initial conditions (λ_L > 0). Pathological beta oscillations.

determinacy_spectrum.name: Chaotic → QU
determinacy_spectrum.description: Limbic system spans chaotic dynamics to quantum-uncertain territory at synaptic scale

determinacy_spectrum.name: Quantum Uncertain
determinacy_spectrum.description: Heisenberg-bounded, security-relevant indeterminacy at cortical synapses

wave_equation.L: Length of one wave in its medium (meters)
wave_equation.note: λ and S are deprecated symbols. Use L everywhere.

ultrasound_tissue.medium: Acoustic in soft tissue (not EM — separate vector)

allocations.name: ELF (Extremely Low Frequency)
allocations.notes: US Navy submarine comms (76 Hz Clam Lake, 45 Hz Republic). IS neural frequency. Penetrates everything on Earth. Direct gamma/alpha/theta entrainment.
allocations.historical: Operational 1989-2004 (US). Russia, China maintain similar capability.

allocations.name: SLF (Super Low Frequency)
allocations.notes: Overlaps high-gamma and DBS therapeutic range (130 Hz). Direct motor coordination and cognitive binding disruption.

allocations.name: ULF (Ultra Low Frequency)
allocations.notes: Cochlear frequency range. Direct attack vector for auditory BCIs. Subharmonics reach any neural band.

allocations.name: VLF (Very Low Frequency)
allocations.notes: Submarine comms, navigation. Penetrates buildings, rock, skulls. Stealth carrier for envelope-modulated neural attacks. Attacker selects target via modulation frequency.

allocations.name: BCI Analog Front-End
allocations.notes: Amplification, filtering, ADC. Current BCI operating range. All neural frequencies pass through here.

allocations.name: Power Line Harmonics
allocations.notes: Environmental background. 50/60 Hz in gamma range. Harmonics reach beta/alpha. Could provide cover for targeted injection.

allocations.name: LF (Low Frequency)
allocations.notes: Navigation beacons (LORAN legacy), time signals. Spoofable. Envelope attacks.

allocations.name: MF (Medium Frequency / AM broadcast)
allocations.notes: AM radio band. Licensed but widely accessible transmitters. Two nearby AM stations create beat frequencies in neural range.

allocations.name: HF (High Frequency)
allocations.notes: Military HF comms, over-the-horizon radar. No line of sight needed — ionospheric skip. Global reach with envelope/TI attacks.

allocations.name: VHF (Very High Frequency)
allocations.notes: FM radio, TV broadcast, military aviation, marine. L approaching body scale. Contains both public and restricted allocations.

allocations.name: UHF Military (MILSATCOM)
allocations.notes: CRITICAL: Adjacent to BCI MICS telemetry (402-405 MHz). Intermodulation trivial. 398 MHz mil + 402 MHz BCI = 4 Hz beat → theta → N4 thalamus. The BCI's own telemetry weaponized.

allocations.name: MICS (Medical Implant Communication Service)
allocations.notes: BCI telemetry band. FCC Part 95. Not an attack frequency itself, but participates in intermodulation attacks when paired with nearby military UHF.

allocations.name: UHF Public (ISM, cellular)
allocations.notes: ISM 433 MHz, cellular 700-900 MHz. L at body/head scale. Consumer accessible.

allocations.name: L-Band (GPS, satellite)
allocations.notes: GPS L1 (1.575 GHz), military satellite. L ≈ head diameter. Pulsed with PRF in neural range selects target. Focused delivery at head scale.

allocations.name: BLE / WiFi / ISM 2.4 GHz
allocations.notes: Current BCI wireless link (Neuralink BLE). L ≈ 12.5 cm (cortical scale). Public access = anyone can transmit here.

allocations.name: S-Band (military radar, Frey effect)
allocations.notes: Microwave auditory effect (Frey, 1962). Pulsed microwave → thermoelastic expansion → cochlea perceives as sound. 'Havana Syndrome' range. PRF selects neural target. N2 auditory brainstem, N7 auditory cortex.

allocations.name: C-Band (satellite, 5G mid-band)
allocations.notes: 5G mid-band (3.5-4.2 GHz), satellite downlink. L at cortical/electrode scale. Growing public deployment.

allocations.name: X-Band (military radar)
allocations.notes: Military fire-control radar, weather radar. L at electrode array scale. Can heat implant components. Surface cortex and I0 electrode damage.

allocations.name: Ku/Ka-Band (military satellite, 5G mm-wave)
allocations.notes: Military SATCOM, 5G mm-wave (28 GHz, 39 GHz). L at electrode/tissue scale. Shallow penetration but can disrupt I0 boundary.

allocations.name: V/W-Band (military comms, directed energy research)
allocations.notes: Military point-to-point comms, directed energy research. L at single-electrode scale. Highly absorbed by atmosphere — short range but precise.

allocations.name: Active Denial System (ADS)
allocations.notes: 95 GHz directed energy. Excites water molecules in top 0.4 mm of skin. For implants near surface: electrode heating, tissue damage at I0 boundary. Destroys interface integrity.
allocations.mechanism: Thermal absorption, not frequency coupling. Damages I0 physically.

allocations.name: Terahertz (THz gap)
allocations.notes: Mostly unexplored for neural effects. Molecular resonance frequencies. Could affect electrode-tissue chemistry. Research frontier for nation-states. L at cellular/molecular scale.

attack_coupling_mechanisms.name: Direct Frequency Match
attack_coupling_mechanisms.description: Attack frequency is already at the neural target frequency. Walks through I0.

attack_coupling_mechanisms.name: Harmonic Coupling
attack_coupling_mechanisms.formula: f_attack = n × f_neural (super) or f_neural / n (sub)
attack_coupling_mechanisms.description: Neural tissue is nonlinear — generates harmonics. Higher n = weaker coupling.

attack_coupling_mechanisms.name: Envelope Modulation
attack_coupling_mechanisms.formula: Carrier at f_carrier, modulated at f_mod. Tissue responds to f_mod.
attack_coupling_mechanisms.description: Stealth attack. High-frequency carrier hides low-frequency neural-range modulation. tACS principle.

attack_coupling_mechanisms.name: Temporal Interference
attack_coupling_mechanisms.formula: f_beat = |f₁ - f₂|. Tissue at intersection responds to f_beat.
attack_coupling_mechanisms.description: Two kHz+ signals create neural-range beat frequency. Can target deep brain structures. Grossman et al. 2017, Cell.

attack_coupling_mechanisms.name: Intermodulation (BCI as weapon)
attack_coupling_mechanisms.formula: f_attack = f_neural - f_BCI. Attack + BCI's own signal mix in nonlinear tissue.
attack_coupling_mechanisms.coupling_strength: Variable — depends on BCI signal power
attack_coupling_mechanisms.description: Most dangerous. Attacker's signal mixes with BCI's therapeutic/telemetry signal. BCI becomes part of the attack chain. Attack frequency can be inside normal operating range.

attack_propagation.equation: P_neural(f_N) = Σᵢ [ H(fᵢ) × G(fᵢ, f_N) × P_attack(fᵢ) × A(fᵢ) ]
attack_propagation.P_neural: Power delivered to neural band at frequency f_N
attack_propagation.H: I0 transfer function — electrode impedance at frequency fᵢ (frequency-dependent)
attack_propagation.G: Coupling gain — sum of all 5 mechanisms (DIRECT + HARMONIC + ENVELOPE + TEMPORAL_INTERFERENCE + INTERMODULATION)
attack_propagation.A: Access coefficient — 1 if threat actor can transmit at fᵢ, 0 otherwise. Nation-states: A=1 everywhere.

resonance_shield.concept: Active EM cancellation at I0 boundary
resonance_shield.principle: Destructive interference — opposite phase, matched amplitude cancels incoming wave
requirements: Detection: sensor array to measure incoming EM (frequency, phase, amplitude)
Computation: real-time cancellation signal calculation (< fraction of wave period)
Emission: antenna array to broadcast cancellation field
Whitelist: pass authorized frequencies (therapeutic stim, MRI), cancel unauthorized

dual_use.security: Protects against adversarial pulsed EM, ELF entrainment, Frey effect attacks
dual_use.clinical: Enables MRI compatibility for BCI patients (cancel RF excitation at Larmor frequency, gradient switching)

resonance_shield.status: Concept — requires hardware research. NSP specification should define as I0 hardware requirement.

CONSUMER.description: Non-invasive EEG headsets for consumer/wellness use

CONSUMER_PRO.description: Higher-channel consumer EEG with cloud/research features

RESEARCH.description: Research-grade EEG systems for laboratory use

CLINICAL.description: Clinical-grade EEG/ECoG for medical diagnosis and monitoring

IMPLANTED.description: Fully implanted intracortical BCIs with direct neural contact

AUDITORY_PROSTHESIS.description: Cochlear implants and auditory cortex prostheses — NSP Phase 1 target

OPTICAL.description: Optical neural interfaces — fNIRS, optogenetics, fiber photometry

interface_types.quantum_mechanism: Ion channel tunneling, charge transfer at metal-tissue boundary
interface_types.examples: Neuralink N1, BrainGate Utah array, ECoG grids

interface_types.quantum_mechanism: Photon coherence, stimulated emission, photoelectric effects
Spin dynamics, magnetic resonance at molecular scale
NV-center spin readout, OPM atomic coherence, SQUID flux quantization

threat_registry.framework: QIF (Quantum Indeterministic Framework for Neural Security)

mitre_compatibility.id_range: T2001-T2899 (avoids collision with MITRE ATT&CK T1001-T1659)
mitre_compatibility.tactic_ids: Standard MITRE TA#### where applicable, TA0050-TA0053 for BCI-specific
mitre_compatibility.note: Designed for future MITRE collaboration — our IDs can be adopted or cross-referenced without conflict.

tactics.name: Reconnaissance
tactics.description: Profiling neural signals, mapping BCI networks, fingerprinting devices

tactics.name: Initial Access
tactics.description: Gaining access to BCI system or neural pathway via electrodes, RF, firmware

tactics.name: Execution
tactics.description: Running attack payload on BCI hardware or injecting malicious neural signals

tactics.name: Persistence
tactics.description: Maintaining foothold across BCI sessions via calibration, learned patterns

tactics.name: Defense Evasion
tactics.description: Avoiding detection by QI metrics, coherence checks, anomaly detectors

tactics.name: Collection
tactics.description: Harvesting neural data, cognitive states, memory patterns, ERP responses

tactics.name: Impact
tactics.description: Disrupting neural function, causing physical harm, denying BCI service

tactics.name: Neural Manipulation
tactics.description: Direct neural state modification via stimulation, entrainment, or signal injection. No MITRE equivalent.

tactics.name: Cognitive Exploitation
tactics.description: Exploiting cognitive processes (memory, attention, identity, agency). No MITRE equivalent.

tactics.name: Directed Energy
tactics.description: EM/RF attacks on neural tissue or BCI hardware via frequency-domain coupling. No MITRE equivalent.

tactics.name: Adversarial ML
tactics.description: Attacking BCI decoder/classifier models via poisoning, backdoors, or adversarial inputs. Partial overlap with MITRE TA0042 (Resource Development).

mitre.note: Maps to Content Injection (T1659) and Input Injection (T1674) — inject false content into BCI data stream

techniques.notes: Inject crafted signals mimicking legitimate brain activity at electrode-tissue boundary. Classical detection via impedance anomaly. QI coherence metric flags phase/timing inconsistency.

mitre.note: Maps to Data Encrypted for Impact (T1486, ransomware analog) + Service Stop (T1489, lock neural function)

techniques.notes: Disrupt or lock neural function via stimulation manipulation. Closed-loop devices (RNS, DBS) most vulnerable. QI detects anomalous coherence collapse. Distinct from Neural DoS: ransomware implies conditional restoration.

mitre.note: Network sniffing adapted for BCI signals

techniques.notes: Passive interception of neural signals. At I0: quantum measurement disturbs state (detectable). At S1-S3: classical RF interception, most consumer BCIs transmit unencrypted. Merges ONI-T001 (Signal Profiling), ONI-T023 (Unencrypted Data Interception).

mitre.note: Adversary-in-the-middle adapted for BCI data path

techniques.notes: Intercept and modify signals at I0 boundary or BCI telemetry. No-cloning theorem prevents perfect copy of quantum neural states. Bell test detects entanglement disruption.

mitre.note: NO MITRE EQUIVALENT. Exploit ion channel quantum tunneling to inject false synaptic events. Physics-based attack with no digital analog.

techniques.notes: Exploit ion channel quantum tunneling to inject false synaptic events. Detectable via Q_tunnel term anomaly in QI equation. Requires understanding of target's ion channel tunneling profile.

mitre.note: NO MITRE EQUIVALENT. THz stimulation triggers Davydov solitons in SNARE protein complexes. Quantum-biological — no digital analog.

techniques.notes: THz stimulation triggers Davydov solitons in SNARE protein complexes, causing false neurotransmitter release at I0. Exploits energy transport in alpha-helix protein structures.

mitre.note: Maps to Data Manipulation (T1565) — exploit neural data protocol to alter transmitted data

techniques.notes: Exploit weaknesses in BCI data protocols to inject commands or alter data formatting, bypassing security controls. Targets the digital decoding/telemetry pipeline.

mitre.note: Maps to Adversary-in-the-Middle (T1557) + Transmitted Data Manipulation (T1565.002) — intercept and modify motor/cognitive commands

techniques.notes: Intercept and modify motor commands or cognitive instructions in transit through the BCI system. Targets closed-loop stimulation devices. Intent verification detects command-intent mismatch.

mitre.note: Maps to Content Injection (T1659) + Hardware Additions (T1200) — RF device injects synthetic brainwave patterns

techniques.notes: Inject RF signals calibrated to neural frequencies through BCI's own antenna or nearby transmitter. Synthetic brainwave patterns bypass analog front-end filters designed for biological signals.

mitre.note: NO MITRE EQUIVALENT. Directed energy weapon — physics-based coupling at neural frequency (3-76 Hz). Government-restricted. Closest ICS: Manipulation of Control (T0831).

techniques.notes: 3-76 Hz government-restricted. IS neural frequency. Penetrates globally. Direct gamma/alpha/theta cortical entrainment. US Navy operated at 76 Hz (Clam Lake) and 45 Hz (Republic). Russia, China maintain capability.

mitre.note: NO MITRE EQUIVALENT. Nonlinear tissue mixing of attacker + BCI signals produces neural-range beat frequency. Novel physics-based coupling.

techniques.notes: UHF-Mil (225-400 MHz) + MICS (402 MHz) = neural-range beat frequency. BCI's own telemetry signal becomes part of the attack. 398 MHz mil + 402 MHz BCI = 4 Hz theta. Most dangerous coupling mechanism. QI CANNOT detect from signal data alone -- requires resonance shield.

mitre.note: NO MITRE EQUIVALENT. Pulsed microwave auditory/neural effect (Frey effect). Directed energy weapon — no digital/cyber analog.

techniques.notes: S-band (2-4 GHz) pulsed microwave. Thermoelastic expansion causes cochlea to perceive as sound. Havana Syndrome model. PRF selects neural target: 40 Hz gamma, 10 Hz alpha, 4 Hz theta, 1 Hz delta.

mitre.note: NO MITRE EQUIVALENT. Weaponized temporal interference stimulation (Grossman 2017). Two kHz+ signals produce neural-range beat at depth.

techniques.notes: Two kHz+ signals create neural-range beat frequency at tissue intersection. Can target deep brain structures non-invasively. Licensed frequencies -- lower barrier than restricted.

mitre.note: NO MITRE EQUIVALENT. Weaponized tACS — any carrier AM-modulated at neural frequency. Tissue demodulates. Lowest barrier to entry.

techniques.notes: Any carrier frequency modulated at neural frequency. Tissue demodulates the envelope. Stealth: carrier looks normal, attack is in the modulation. Lowest barrier to entry (PUBLIC access). tACS therapeutic principle weaponized.

mitre.note: NO MITRE EQUIVALENT. Physical thermal destruction of electrode-tissue boundary. Closest ICS: Damage to Property (T0879). Nation-state only.

techniques.notes: mm-wave/ADS (95 GHz) directed energy. Excites water molecules in top 0.4mm of skin. For surface implants: electrode heating, tissue damage at I0 boundary. Destroys interface integrity. Nation-state only.

mitre.note: Supply chain via ML model poisoning

sources: Zhang et al. 2024 (Professor X attack on EEG models)
techniques.notes: Backdoor injected during BCI decoder training. Trigger pattern in EEG input activates attacker-chosen output. Model performs normally on clean inputs. Demonstrated on P300, MI, SSVEP paradigms.

mitre.note: Backdoor via pre-trained BCI model

techniques.notes: Backdoor persists through transfer learning from pre-trained BCI models. Attacker poisons upstream model, downstream users inherit the backdoor. Common in EEG foundation model paradigm.

mitre.note: Maps to Stored Data Manipulation (T1565.001) — adversarial perturbation corrupts BCI signal processing filters

techniques.notes: Craft minimal perturbations that pass through BCI analog/digital filters but flip decoder output. Exploits gap between what filters remove and what classifiers rely on.

mitre.note: Maps to Stored Data Manipulation (T1565.001) — input-agnostic adversarial perturbation that degrades any BCI decoder

techniques.notes: Single perturbation pattern that fools BCI decoder regardless of input. Works across subjects and sessions. Pre-computed offline, applied in real-time. Lower sophistication than targeted attacks.

mitre.note: Maps to Data from Local System (T1005) + Data from Cloud Storage (T1530) — infer membership in BCI training dataset

techniques.notes: Determine if a specific person's neural data was used to train a BCI model. Reveals participation in clinical trials, neurological conditions. GDPR Article 9 implications.

mitre.note: Maps to Data from Cloud Storage (T1530) — extract private neural data from federated learning gradients

techniques.notes: Reconstruct individual neural data from shared gradients in federated BCI training. Multi-site clinical trials share model updates. Gradient inversion recovers raw EEG with high fidelity.

mitre.note: Maps to Transmitted Data Manipulation (T1565.002) — falsify neurofeedback signals in closed-loop BCI

techniques.notes: Manipulate neurofeedback display or stimulation parameters in closed-loop BCIs. User adapts brain state to false feedback, causing maladaptive neuroplasticity. Therapeutic BCIs (ADHD, depression) most vulnerable.

mitre.note: Maps to Transmitted Data Manipulation (T1565.002) — perturb closed-loop to trigger cascading destabilization

techniques.notes: Small adversarial perturbation injected into closed-loop BCI amplifies through feedback cycle. Each loop iteration increases deviation until system destabilizes. NeuroPace RNS, DBS with LFP sensing vulnerable.

mitre.note: Maps to Network DoS (T1498) + Endpoint DoS (T1499) — overwhelm neural tissue via electrode overstimulation

techniques.notes: Overwhelm targeted neurons via continuous high-frequency stimulation through compromised electrodes. Prevents normal neural signaling. Analogous to radio jamming. Implanted BCIs with stimulation capability.

mitre.note: Maps to Network DoS (T1498) + Endpoint DoS (T1499) — flood neural pathways with excessive stimulation

techniques.notes: Flood neural tissue with maximum stimulation across all available electrodes simultaneously. Unlike jamming (targeted), flooding is broad-area saturation. Can trigger seizures. Emergency shutoff required.

mitre.note: Active scanning adapted for neural tissue mapping

techniques.notes: Systematically probe neural tissue via low-amplitude stimulation pulses to map functional connectivity, identify responsive regions, and characterize individual neural signatures. Prerequisite for targeted attacks.

mitre.note: Maps to Transmitted Data Manipulation (T1565.002) — selectively drop/modify neural signal packets to alter perceived brain state

techniques.notes: Compromised BCI firmware selectively drops or forwards neural signals based on content. Filter out specific cognitive states while passing others. Subtle censorship of neural output.

mitre.note: Denial of service adapted for neural systems

techniques.notes: Overwhelm neural pathways with excessive stimulation or signal flooding causing temporary dysfunction or distress. Rate limiting at I0 and emergency shutdown are primary defenses.

mitre.note: Maps loosely to Data Manipulation (T1565) — hijack motor commands to produce involuntary movement. BCI-specific severity beyond traditional data manipulation.

techniques.notes: Force involuntary motor actions by injecting false motor commands through compromised BCI motor interfaces. Intent verification compares commands against detected cognitive intent. Physical safety interlocks required.

mitre.note: Valid account access via neural biometric spoofing

techniques.notes: Replicate user's neural signature to bypass BCI authentication. Classical biometrics (ERP templates, brainprint) are partially spoofable. If quantum neural signatures exist, no-cloning makes them physically unclonable.

mitre.note: NO MITRE EQUIVALENT. Long-term psychological continuity attack via gradual neural stimulation drift. No digital/cyber analog exists.

techniques.notes: Long-term subtle manipulation of cognitive patterns leading to gradual personality changes or identity confusion. Targets L14 (Identity/Cognitive Sovereignty). Detectable via longitudinal QI baseline comparison. Neurorights: psychological continuity.

mitre.note: NO MITRE EQUIVALENT. Direct cognitive manipulation via hippocampal stimulation. No digital/cyber analog — requires neural interface.

techniques.notes: Inject false information into working memory circuits via targeted hippocampal/PFC stimulation. User perceives false memories or corrupted working memory contents as genuine. Closed-loop memory BCIs most vulnerable.

mitre.note: Maps to Automated Collection (T1119) — trigger P300 evoked responses to involuntarily extract yes/no answers. BCI-specific interrogation technique.

techniques.notes: Present stimuli designed to elicit P300 ERP responses revealing private knowledge (PINs, faces, locations). BCI app stores could embed interrogation stimuli in games. Demonstrated on consumer EEG (EMOTIV, NeuroSky).

mitre.note: Maps to Automated Collection (T1119) + Data from Local System (T1005) — decode covert speech from neural signals. BCI-specific cognitive extraction.

techniques.notes: Decode inner speech from neural signals without user consent. High-density arrays (Neuralink, Utah) approach word-level accuracy. Consumer EEG at phoneme level. Merges with 'Covert Speech Decoding' from 2024-2026 research.

mitre.note: NO MITRE EQUIVALENT. Manipulate user's sense of agency/free will via BCI stimulation. No digital/cyber analog — neurological attack.

techniques.notes: Manipulate sense of agency -- user believes externally triggered actions are self-initiated, or vice versa. Targets basal ganglia (motor selection) and PFC (executive control). Neurorights: cognitive liberty.

mitre.note: Credential access via neural biometric extraction

techniques.notes: Extract the user's unique brainprint (ERP template, spectral fingerprint) for later replay/spoofing. Unlike passwords, neural biometrics cannot be changed. Permanent compromise if extracted.

mitre.note: NO MITRE EQUIVALENT. Corrupt user's neural self-model / body representation. No digital/cyber analog — neurological identity attack.

techniques.notes: Corrupt the neural representation of self (body ownership, self-other boundary, autobiographical memory). Targets insula, TPJ, mPFC. Could cause depersonalization, dissociation, or false self-recognition. Neurorights: mental integrity.

mitre.note: Phishing adapted for BCI context

techniques.notes: Present carefully designed visual/auditory/haptic stimuli through BCI applications to elicit specific neural responses (P300, SSVEP, emotional) that reveal private information or prime the brain for subsequent attack. BCI app store is the attack surface.

techniques.quantum: Enhanced (data minimization via QI privacy filter)

mitre.note: Maps to Automated Collection (T1119) + Data from Local System (T1005) — infer sensitive attributes (health, emotion, identity) from neural metadata

techniques.notes: Infer sensitive personal attributes (health conditions, sexual orientation, political beliefs, cognitive decline) from BCI usage metadata and neural signal statistics without decoding content. Side-channel on cognition.

mitre.note: Network sniffing / side-channel via BLE emissions

techniques.notes: Extract neural data from BLE/RF emissions via timing, power, or EM side-channels. All wireless BCIs vulnerable. Consumer devices (Muse, EMOTIV) transmit unencrypted. Merges ONI-T002 (Side-Channel Analysis).

mitre.note: Direct MITRE mapping: supply chain compromise

techniques.notes: Tamper with BCI hardware/firmware during manufacturing or distribution. Firmware rootkits persist across updates. Merges ONI-T006 (Firmware Backdoor). QI-enhanced firmware attestation detects unauthorized modifications.

mitre.note: Exploit public-facing BCI cloud API

techniques.notes: Compromise cloud services processing neural data (EMOTIV Cortex API, Neuralink cloud). Data exfiltration, model poisoning, API manipulation. PQC/QKD protects data in transit.

mitre.note: Maps to Adversary-in-the-Middle (T1557, intercept) + Data from Cloud Storage (T1530, store). Record encrypted BCI traffic now, decrypt when quantum computers arrive.

techniques.notes: Record encrypted BCI traffic now, decrypt when quantum computers arrive (2030-2035). Neural data is permanently sensitive -- can't change your brain like a password. PQC (ML-KEM/Kyber) prevents. 10-20 year implant lifetime > quantum arrival.

mitre.note: Software supply chain via OTA update mechanism

techniques.notes: Compromise OTA firmware update mechanism to push malicious updates to implanted BCIs. Update channel becomes persistent backdoor. Secure boot + cryptographic attestation + rollback protection required.

mitre.note: Maps to Software Deployment Tools (T1072, mass compromise vector) + Network DoS (T1498). Coordinated attack on standardized BCI platform.

techniques.notes: Coordinated attack exploiting standardized BCI platforms affecting millions simultaneously. Yale Digital Ethics Center worst-case scenario. Monoculture risk: one vulnerability, all devices. Merges ONI-T024 (Mass Neural Manipulation).

mitre.note: Hardware additions — physical electrode manipulation

techniques.notes: Physical manipulation or replacement of neural electrodes to inject malicious signals or intercept legitimate neural data. Impedance monitoring detects electrode tampering. Tamper-evident seals for implants.

mitre.note: Weak BCI authentication exploitation

techniques.notes: Exploit weak or absent authentication on BCI wireless interfaces. Many consumer and older clinical devices assume connection implies authorization. No pairing, no encryption, no auth.

mitre.note: Data from local system — neural data access

techniques.notes: Unauthorized access to recorded neural data across any band. Harvest raw EEG from consumer devices, decode intent/emotion. GDPR Article 9 (special category data). NSP end-to-end encryption from I0 to cloud.

mitre.note: Maps to Automated Collection (T1119) — automated harvesting of event-related potentials (P300, N400, etc.) from BCI signals

techniques.notes: Extract event-related potentials (P300, N170, N400) that reveal cognitive states, recognition, and decision-making processes. BCI apps can embed covert stimulus-response protocols.

mitre.note: Maps to Automated Collection (T1119) + Data from Local System (T1005) — passive collection of emotional/cognitive state from neural signals

techniques.notes: Record patterns that reveal attention, emotion, fatigue, or other cognitive states without user awareness. Consumer BCI apps routinely over-collect. Attention-tracking in workplace BCIs.

mitre.note: Maps to Data from Local System (T1005) — extract memory-encoded neural patterns. BCI-specific: no traditional system stores 'memories' as data.

techniques.notes: Extract memory-related neural patterns revealing personal experiences, knowledge, or intentions. Targets hippocampal activity. High-density implants (Neuralink, Utah Array) approach memory-trace resolution.

mitre.note: Maps to Network DoS (T1498) + Data Manipulation (T1565) — nation-state cognitive warfare leveraging BCI infrastructure at scale

techniques.notes: State-level exploitation of BCI infrastructure for cognitive warfare: mass influence, decision degradation, combat effectiveness reduction. Combines multiple techniques (T2101-T2106, T2506). Military BCI programs (DARPA N3, BrainSTORMS) as targets.

mitre.note: Maps to Automated Collection (T1119) + Adversary-in-the-Middle (T1557) — mass neural data interception and collection for surveillance

techniques.notes: Systematic collection of neural data from consumer BCI populations for surveillance purposes. Workplace attention monitoring, law enforcement lie detection, social credit via neural markers. Neurorights: mental privacy.

mitre.note: Network service discovery adapted for BCI mesh

techniques.notes: Discover topology of BCI networks: communication pathways between electrodes, processing units, and external interfaces. Prerequisite for targeted attacks. Deploy honeypot nodes and dynamic addressing.

mitre.note: Maps to Stored Data Manipulation (T1565.001, corrupt calibration) + Event Triggered Execution (T1546, persist via calibration reload)

techniques.notes: Subtly corrupt BCI calibration data to maintain influence over signal interpretation across device resets. Cryptographically signed calibration data prevents. Recalibration audits detect drift.

mitre.note: Maps to Event Triggered Execution (T1546) — persist via learned neural pathway patterns that trigger on brain state events

techniques.notes: Embed recurring attack patterns that survive system resets by exploiting learned neural pathways or stored calibration data. Leverages neuroplasticity -- brain adapts to malicious patterns, making them harder to remove.

mitre.note: Maps to Event Triggered Execution (T1546) — cross-session persistence via neural pathway modification that survives device reset

techniques.notes: Persistent modification of neural pathway configurations or cognitive associations that survive across BCI sessions. Targets long-term potentiation mechanisms. Session isolation prevents cross-session contamination.

mitre.note: Maps to Masquerading (T1036) — mimic legitimate neural coherence patterns to evade QIF detection

techniques.notes: Craft malicious signals that maintain legitimate coherence scores (Cs) to bypass QI metric. Directly attacks QIF's detection mechanism. Defense: multi-factor signal validation, behavioral analysis beyond coherence, ensemble detection.

mitre.note: Maps to Obfuscated Files or Information (T1027) — slow parameter drift stays below detection threshold to evade monitoring

techniques.notes: Slowly modify neural parameters below detection thresholds to accumulate significant changes over time. Exploit adaptive baseline algorithms. Cumulative change detection and trend analysis are primary defenses.

mitre.note: Maps to Obfuscated Files or Information (T1027) — inject calibrated noise to mask malicious signals from QI detection

techniques.notes: Add carefully calibrated noise to mask malicious signal components from detection algorithms. Targets QI's sigma-phi (phase) and sigma-gamma (amplitude) terms. Multi-channel cross-validation detects inconsistent noise patterns.

deprecated.reason: Legacy ONI-era threat matrix (24 techniques, ONI-T### IDs). Superseded by this registry.
deprecated.migration: All ONI-T### techniques merged into T2000+ range. See legacy_ids field on each technique.
